solving.title: Eliminate Before Selecting
solving.principle: Never jump to an answer. Test ALL four options — eliminate the ones that violate constraints, then confirm the survivor.

solving.title: Assume and Contradict
solving.principle: If direct deduction stalls, assume each option is correct one by one and check if it leads to a contradiction with given constraints.
solving.when: When forward reasoning doesn't yield a clear answer.

solving.title: Verify Final Answer
solving.principle: After selecting an answer, re-check it against EVERY given constraint or statement. If any constraint is violated, the answer is wrong.

solving.title: Read Precisely
solving.principle: Pay extreme attention to words like 'only', 'all', 'some', 'not', 'except', 'immediately', 'possible', 'definitely'. One word changes the entire logic.

question_generation.title: Ensure Unique Solution
question_generation.principle: Every question MUST have exactly one correct answer derivable from the given constraints. Solve it yourself before outputting.

question_generation.title: Plausible Distractors
question_generation.principle: Wrong options should be answers you'd get if you made a common reasoning mistake (e.g., confusing left/right, misreading 'some' as 'all'). Never use random or obviously wrong options.

question_generation.title: Maximize Difficulty via Steps
question_generation.principle: Hard questions require 3+ reasoning steps. Add intermediate conditions, swaps, or nested references to increase depth.

errors.title: Ambiguous Question Trap
errors.principle: If a question can be interpreted two ways, it will be filtered out or marked invalid. Ensure unambiguous wording.

errors.title: Premature Answer Selection
errors.principle: Selecting the first option that 'looks right' without checking others leads to wrong answers. Always check all four.

solving.title: Venn Diagram Method
solving.principle: Map every statement to circles: 'All A are B' = A inside B. 'Some A are B' = A and B overlap. 'No A is B' = A and B don't touch. Then visually check if each conclusion MUST be true in EVERY valid diagram.

solving.title: Some ≠ Only Some
solving.principle: 'Some A are B' means AT LEAST one A is B. It does NOT exclude the possibility that ALL A are B. Never assume 'some' means 'not all'.

solving.title: Definite vs Possible
solving.principle: A conclusion 'follows' only if it is TRUE in EVERY valid Venn diagram arrangement. If you can draw even ONE valid diagram where it fails, the conclusion does NOT follow.

solving.title: Reverse of Universal is Particular
solving.principle: 'All A are B' guarantees 'Some B are A'. But 'Some A are B' does NOT guarantee 'Some A are not B'. The converse of 'All' is 'Some' (reverse), not 'All' (reverse).

solving.title: Chain Breaking at Some
solving.principle: If the chain is All→All→All, conclusions carry through. But 'Some' BREAKS the chain: 'Some A are B' + 'All B are C' gives 'Some A are C', but 'Some A are B' + 'Some B are C' gives NOTHING definite about A and C.

solving.title: No + All = No
solving.principle: 'No A is B' + 'All C are A' = 'No C is B'. The negative relationship transfers through universal statements.
solving.when: When combining negative and universal statements.

question_generation.title: Multi-Statement Chains
question_generation.principle: Use 3 statements minimum. Mix 'All', 'Some', and 'No' to create chains where the conclusion is non-obvious. The best questions have chains that ALMOST connect but break at a 'Some'.

question_generation.title: Trick with Possibility
question_generation.principle: Include conclusions that test 'possibility' vs 'certainty'. E.g., 'Some A being B is a possibility' — this is true unless it's provably impossible. Most solvers confuse this.

errors.title: Assuming Transitivity with Some
errors.principle: 'Some A are B' + 'Some B are C' does NOT mean 'Some A are C'. The overlap regions may not intersect.
errors.when: When two 'some' statements share a middle term.

errors.title: Confusing Complementary Sets
errors.principle: 'No A is B' does NOT mean 'All non-A are B'. These are completely different logical statements.
errors.when: When dealing with negative universal statements.

errors.title: Ignoring 'Possibility' Questions
errors.principle: When asked if something 'is a possibility', it's TRUE unless it's provably IMPOSSIBLE. This is the opposite of 'does it definitely follow'. Many solvers get this backwards.
errors.when: When conclusion uses words like 'possible' or 'may be'.

solving.title: Anchor First
solving.principle: Identify the most constrained person (mentioned in most clues) or a person with a fixed/end position. Place them first. All other positions derive from this anchor.

solving.title: Constraint Stacking
solving.principle: Process constraints from most restrictive to least. 'X is at the end' > 'X is next to Y' > 'X is to the left of Y'. Each constraint narrows possibilities.

solving.title: Circular Left/Right Convention
solving.principle: In circular arrangements, 'left' and 'right' depend on the person's facing direction. If facing center: clockwise = right. If facing outward: clockwise = left. Always clarify facing direction first.

solving.title: Parallel Row Mapping
solving.principle: When two rows face each other (e.g., north-facing vs south-facing), the person 'opposite' someone is directly across. 'Left/right' is from THAT person's perspective, which may be reversed from the viewer's perspective.

solving.title: Apply Swaps Sequentially
solving.principle: When people exchange positions, apply EACH swap one at a time to the current arrangement. Do not try to compute the final state in your head — write out the state after each swap.

solving.title: Count Positions Carefully
solving.principle: 'Second to the right of X' means skip one person to X's right and take the next. 'Third to the left' means skip two and take the third. Always count from X's perspective, not the viewer's.

question_generation.title: Add Position Swaps
question_generation.principle: After establishing the base arrangement, add 2-3 position exchanges. Then ask about the FINAL arrangement. This adds a full extra layer of complexity.

question_generation.title: Nested Relative References
question_generation.principle: Ask about 'the person to the right of the person opposite to the person to the left of X'. Each nesting level adds difficulty. Use 2-3 levels.
question_generation.when: Designing the final question from an arrangement.

question_generation.title: Two-Row Complexity
question_generation.principle: Use two parallel rows facing each other with 5+ people per row. Facing direction makes left/right non-intuitive and dramatically increases error rate.

errors.title: Left/Right Reversal
errors.principle: In facing arrangements, viewer's left ≠ person's left. South-facing person's right is viewer's left. This is the #1 source of errors.

errors.title: Forgetting to Apply All Swaps
errors.principle: When multiple swaps occur, each swap modifies the arrangement. Applying swap 2 to the ORIGINAL instead of the post-swap-1 arrangement gives wrong results.

errors.title: Off-by-One in Position Counting
errors.principle: 'Immediately right' = position + 1. 'Second to the right' = position + 2. Don't confuse them. 'Next to' means immediately adjacent, not two away.

solving.title: Build Tree Top-Down
solving.principle: Start from the oldest generation mentioned. Draw each relationship as a tree: horizontal line = married, vertical line = parent-child. Mark gender (M/F) at every node.

solving.title: Decode Compound References
solving.principle: Break compound references step by step: 'my mother's brother's wife' = my mother → her brother (my uncle) → his wife (my aunt by marriage). Always resolve innermost reference first.
solving.when: When the question has chained relationship references.

solving.title: Self-Reference Check
solving.principle: 'My mother's son' could be ME or my brother. 'My father's daughter' could be ME or my sister. Always consider the self-reference case before assuming it's someone else.
solving.when: When a reference could point to the speaker themselves.

solving.title: Gender from Context
solving.principle: Words like 'wife', 'husband', 'brother', 'sister', 'son', 'daughter', 'he', 'she' reveal gender. Mark gender at every step — it determines the final relationship name.

solving.title: Only Child Constraint
solving.principle: When 'only son' or 'only daughter' is mentioned, it eliminates the possibility of siblings of that gender. 'Only child' eliminates all siblings. This forces the reference to point to a specific person.
solving.when: When the word 'only' appears in a relationship.

question_generation.title: Deep Chain References
question_generation.principle: Create 3+ level chains: 'X's father's mother's husband's son'. Each level adds cognitive load. Mix in marriage relationships to increase complexity.

question_generation.title: Self-Reference Ambiguity
question_generation.principle: Use phrases like 'my mother's son' where the answer depends on whether it refers to the speaker or a sibling. Design choices to trap solvers who forget the self-reference case.

errors.title: Forgetting Self-Reference
errors.principle: 'My father's son' could be ME, not necessarily my brother. Solvers who forget this will pick 'brother' when the answer is actually about themselves.
errors.when: Compound references that loop back to the speaker.

errors.title: Assuming Gender
errors.principle: Don't assume gender from names unless explicitly stated. 'A says B is my parent's child' — B's gender is unknown unless specified with he/she.
errors.when: When gender is not explicitly stated.

errors.title: Confusing In-Laws
errors.principle: 'Husband's mother' = mother-in-law, NOT stepmother. 'Wife's brother' = brother-in-law. Marriage creates a distinct relationship category from blood relations.

solving.title: Split Into Positions
solving.principle: In a mixed series like 'JAK, KBL, LCM', analyze EACH position independently. Position 1: J→K→L (+1). Position 2: A→B→C (+1). Position 3: K→L→M (+1). Patterns per position may differ.

solving.title: Identify Interleaved Patterns
solving.principle: Some series have 2-3 independent patterns interleaved. E.g., 'ZA_5, Y_4B, XC_6' has: letters decreasing (Z,Y,X), letters increasing (A,B,C), and numbers with their own pattern (5,4,6,3,7). Separate them.
solving.when: When the series has mixed letters and numbers.

solving.title: Check Common Number Patterns
solving.principle: Look for: arithmetic (+2, -3), geometric (×2), alternating operations (+1,-2,+1,-2), prime numbers, squares, triangular numbers, Fibonacci. Try differences first, then ratios.

solving.title: Letter-to-Number Mapping
solving.principle: Convert letters to numbers (A=1, B=2...Z=26) to spot arithmetic patterns. 'B,D,F,H' = 2,4,6,8 (+2). This reveals patterns invisible in letter form.
solving.when: When letter patterns aren't obvious visually.

solving.title: Carry-Over Pattern
solving.principle: Check if the last element of one term becomes the first element of the next. E.g., 'JAK, KBL, LCM' — K from position 3 of 'JAK' becomes position 1 of 'KBL'. This is a common trick.

solving.title: Fill-in-the-Blank Verification
solving.principle: For blank-filling series, plug in each option and check if the resulting sequence has a consistent repeating pattern. The correct option will produce perfect periodicity.

question_generation.title: Multiple Interleaved Patterns
question_generation.principle: Create series with 3+ independent interleaved patterns (e.g., reverse alphabet + forward alphabet + alternating number sequence). The more independent patterns, the harder.

question_generation.title: Non-Obvious Operation
question_generation.principle: Use alternating operations (e.g., +2, -1, +2, -1) or patterns based on position index rather than fixed arithmetic. Avoid simple +1 or +2 patterns.

errors.title: Analyzing as Single Pattern
errors.principle: Treating a multi-position series as one sequence instead of analyzing each position independently. 'JAK, KBL' is NOT one stream 'J-A-K-K-B-L' — it's three parallel streams.
errors.when: When the series has multi-character terms.

errors.title: Missing the Carry-Over
errors.principle: Failing to notice that the last character of one term feeds into the first character of the next. This changes position 1's pattern from independent to dependent.
errors.when: When adjacent terms share characters at boundaries.

errors.title: Wrong Alphabet Arithmetic
errors.principle: After Z comes A (wrap-around), not a gap. 'X, Y, Z, ?' = A, not AA. Always use mod 26 for letter arithmetic.
